text: 24 captives

text: But she has a dying baby.

quote: My own wound also growing so stiff that I could scarce sit down or rise up;
text: She was shot.

quote: Hearing, I say, that I was in this Indian town, he obtained leave to come and see me.

quote: Medfield
text: Medfield

quote: The cause of this rout was, as I thought, their espying some English scouts, who were thereabout.
text: English scouts are spotted.

quote: But to return, we traveled on till night; and in the morning, we must go over the river to Philip's crew.
text: Traveled through the night and crossed the river.

quote: Philip spake to me to make a shirt for his boy, which I did, for which he gave me a shilling
text: King Philip gives her English money for a knitted shirt.

quote: almost as far as Albany

My son being now about a mile from me, I asked liberty to go and see him; they bade me go, and away I went; but quickly lost myself, traveling over hills and through swamps, and could not find the way to him.
text: She gets lost visiting her son a mile away.

quote: My mistress, before we went, was gone to the burial of a papoose, and returning, she found me sitting and reading in my Bible; she snatched it hastily out of my hand, and threw it out of doors. I ran out and catched it up, and put it into my pocket, and never let her see it afterward.
text: Mistress tries to throw away her bible.

quote: He answered me that such a time his master roasted him, and that himself did eat a piece of him, as big as his two fingers, and that he was very good meat.
text: Random Indian tells her her son's been eaten. She doesn't fall for it.

quote: Which he did, and it seems tarried a little too long; for his master was angry with him, and beat him, and then sold him. Then he came running to tell me he had a new master, and that he had given him some ground nuts already.
text: She gets her son sold to a new master because he was gone too long.

quote: I knew not where he was, till I was informed by himself, that he was amongst a smaller parcel of Indians, whose place was about six miles off.
text: Her son was also captured, but alive.

quote: I desired them that they would carry me to Albany upon one of those horses, and sell me for powder
text: She wants to be taken to Albany

quote: a sudden my mistress gives out; she would go no further, but turn back again, and said I must go back again with her
text: Mistress demands to go back and she has to go with her.

quote: It is then hard work to persuade myself, that ever I should be satisfied with bread again

quote: I have seen the extreme vanity of this world: One hour I have been in health, and wealthy, wanting nothing. But the next hour in sickness and wounds, and death, having nothing but sorrow and affliction.
text: she observes how quickly life can change without warning

text: An American Indian wife or woman

My heart skipped within me, thinking they had been Englishmen

text: interesting biblical reference

text: what is the dreadful hour?

text: very puritan, as we discussed on Monday

text: What?

text: Are they asking if she intends to still love an English man? In other words, the only way for her to sleep in a tipi is to sleep with an Indian

quote: I went to see my daughter Mary
text: 2nd daughter, still alive

quote: So I took the Bible
text: Where were all the quotes coming from before?

quote: On the tenth of February 1675, came the Indians with great numbers upon Lancaster
text: February 1675, Lancaster. King Philip's war is from June 1675-April 1678.

quote: About two hours (according to my observation, in that amazing time) they had been about the house before they prevailed to fire it (which they did with flax and hemp, which they brought out of the barn, and there being no defense about the house, only two flankers at two opposite corners and one of them not finished); they fired it once and one ventured out and quenched it, but they quickly fired it again, and that took.
text: House on fire.

quote: Then I took my children (and one of my sisters', hers) to go forth and leave the house: but as soon as we came to the door and appeared, the Indians shot so thick that the bullets rattled against the house, as if one had taken an handful of stones and threw them, so that we were fain to give back.
text: Indians shoot at her and her kids as they try to leave.

quote: No sooner were we out of the house, but my brother-in-law (being before wounded, in defending the house, in or near the throat) fell down dead
text: Brother-in-law dead.

quote: THE FIRST REMOVE
text: An abandoned house on a hill still in sight of Lancaster.

quote: About a mile we went that night, up upon a hill within sight of the town
One of the Indians carried my poor wounded babe upon a horse; it went moaning all along, "I shall die, I shall die." I went on foot after it, with sorrow that cannot be expressed.
text: Her kid is an "it?" And old enough to talk.

quote: At length I took it off the horse, and carried it in my arms till my strength failed, and I fell down with it.
text: Was she or wasn't she shot?

quote: After this it quickly began to snow, and when night came on, they stopped, and now down I must sit in the snow, by a little fire, and a few boughs behind me, with my sick child in my lap; and calling much for water, being now (through the wound) fallen into a violent fever
text: Stopped at a campfire in the snow.

quote: THE SECOND REMOVE
text: Snowy campfire.

quote: Wenimesset, northward of Quabaug.
text: Wenimesset

quote: THE THIRD REMOVE
text: Wenimesset

quote: one Indian would come and tell me one hour that "your master will knock your child in the head," and then a second, and then a third, "your master will quickly knock your child in the head."
text: Threats to kill her wounded daughter.

quote: About two hours in the night, my sweet babe like a lamb departed this life on Feb. 18, 1675.
text: Her daughter dies.

quote: Quinnapin, who was a Sagamore, and married King Philip's wife's sister;
text: Quinnapin, married King Philip's wife's sister?

quote: I went to see my daughter Mary, who was at this same Indian town, at a wigwam not very far off,
text: But she has another living daughter, Mary (10).

quote: There were now besides myself nine English captives in this place (all of them children, except one woman).
text: Indians have 8 children, 2 women captives.

quote: thirty miles from any English town
text: 30 miles away from English towns

quote: At this place we continued about four days.
text: stayed for 4 days

quote: THE FOURTH REMOVE
text: middle of nowhere

quote: Banquaug river
text: Banquaug river

quote: A certain number of us got over the river that night, but it was the night after the Sabbath before all
text: Took 2 days to cross the river.

quote: THE FIFTH REMOVE
text: Banquaug river

quote: We came that day to a great swamp, by the side of which we took up our lodging that night
text: Stopped near a swamp

quote: THE SIXTH REMOVE
text: swamp

quote: Squakeag
text: Squakeag

quote: As we went along, I saw a place where English cattle had been. That was comfort to me, such as it was
text: Come across an abandoned English place.

quote: deserted English fields
text: Did the Indians drive out the English?

quote: THE SEVENTH REMOVE
text: Squakeag

quote: On the morrow morning we must go over the river, i.e. Connecticut, to meet with King Philip
text: Connecticut river?

quote: But now I may say as Psalm 137.1, "By the Rivers of Babylon, there we sate down: yea, we wept when we remembered Zion
text: Babylon and Zion

quote: Then I went to see King Philip
text: Ah, King Philip is an Indian. Aka [Metacomet](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metacomet). This is taking place shortly before King Philip's war.

quote: Marlborough's Praying Indians, which Capt. Mosely brought to Boston
text: Marlborough. Confused by rest of this passage. I assume "Praying" means Christian.

quote: King Philip
Northampton
text: Northampton

quote: THE EIGHTH REMOVE
text: King Philip's camp. In Connecticut?

quote: THE NINTH REMOVE
text: 5 miles up river from Philip's camp

quote: THE TENTH REMOVE
text: 3/4 of a mile further up river

quote: I took my load at my back, and quickly we came to wade over the river; and passed over tiresome and wearisome hills
text: Crossed the river and took to hilly land.

quote: THE ELEVENTH REMOVE
text: travelling up river and over hills

quote: Nux
text: Presumably a good thing. Seems to mean "a thing of no value." Actually means "nut" or similar.

quote: But the thoughts of my going homeward (for so we bent our course)
text: They seem to be going back to English territory.

quote: THE TWELFTH REMOVE
text: 2 miles from the Connecticut river.

quote: five or six miles down the river into a mighty thicket of brush; where we abode almost a fortnight
text: 5 or 6 miles down river (not towards the bay)

quote: THE THIRTEENTH REMOVE
text: in the brush, further downriver

quote: A squaw moved it down again, at which I looked up, and she threw a handful of ashes in mine eyes
text: The Indians are kind of jerks.

quote: Hadley
text: Hadley

quote: With that my mistress rises up, and take up a stick big enough to have killed me, and struck at me with it. But I stepped out, and she struck the stick into the mat of the wigwam
text: Attempted defiance

quote: They had turned him out of the wigwam, and with him an Indian papoose, almost dead (whose parents had been killed), in a bitter cold day, without fire or clothes.
text: Englishman laying on the ground in a shirt with an orphaned baby.

quote: So his master carried him away, and I never saw him afterward, till I saw him at Piscataqua in Portsmouth
text: Last time she sees her son. He seems to be in good hands.

quote: THE FOURTEENTH REMOVE
text: on the move towards Baytowns

quote: THE FIFTEENTH REMOVE
text: Banquang river

quote: THE SIXTEENTH REMOVE
text: across the Banquang river

quote: At night we came to an Indian town
text: Indian town

quote: THE SEVENTEENTH REMOVE
text: indian town

quote: THE EIGHTEENTH REMOVE
text: a second indian town

quote: THE NINETEENTH REMOVE
text: trying to get to Wachusett, near Sudbury

quote: I saw Wachusett hills
text: within sight of Wachusett

quote: Going along, having indeed my life, but little spirit, Philip, who was in the company, came up and took me by the hand, and said, two weeks more and you shall be mistress again
text: King Philip tells her she's going to see her master?

quote: He asked me, when I washed me? I told him not this month. Then he fetched me some water himself, and bid me wash, and gave me the glass to see how I looked; and bid his squaw give me something to eat.
text: Her master lets her bathe and gets her food.

quote: Another was Wattimore [Weetamoo] with whom I had lived and served all this while.
text: She had been traveling with her master's second wife.

quote: Weetamoo's maid came to call me home, at which I fell aweeping. Then the old squaw told me, to encourage me, that if I wanted victuals, I should come to her, and that I should lie there in her wigwam.
text: Second wife wants her back; first wife tells her to come to her for food and shelter at night.

quote: I understood that Weetamoo thought that if she should let me go and serve with the old squaw, she would be in danger to lose not only my service, but the redemption pay also.
text: Second wife wants to keep her in her wigwam so she gets paid the ransom, basically.

quote: Tom and Peter
text: Tom and Peter?

quote: So that fearing the worst, I durst not send to my husband, though there were some thoughts of his coming to redeem and fetch me, not knowing what might follow.
text: How would she have sent for her husband?

quote: Sagamores met to consult about the captives, and called me to them to inquire how much my husband would give to redeem me.
text: The General Court of the Sagamores sets her ransom.

quote: ut they would not hear of that, but sent that message to Boston, that for twenty pounds I should be redeemed. It was a Praying Indian that wrote their letter for them.
text: A Christian Indian writes to Boston for her ransom.

quote: There was another Praying Indian, who told me, that he had a brother, that would not eat horse
text: Lots of Praying Indian stories follow:

quote: One Englishman they brought along with them: and he said, it was too true, for they had made sad work at Sudbury, as indeed it proved.
text: Then they go out and attack Sudbury?

quote: When they went, they acted as if the devil had told them that they should gain the victory; and now they acted as if the devil had told them they should have a fall
text: They left happy and rejoicing, came back quietly and as if they'd lost. But she didn't think they'd lost any men.

quote: Whither it were so or no, I cannot tell, but so it proved, for quickly they began to fall, and so held on that summer, till they came to utter ruin.
text: They did eventually get destroyed (by the english presumably).

quote: Which I did, and as I was eating, another Indian said to me, he seems to be your good friend, but he killed two Englishmen at Sudbury, and there lie their clothes behind you: I looked behind me, and there I saw bloody clothes, with bullet-holes in them.
text: An Indian that would feed her often told her he'd killed two Englishmen at Sudbury and had their clothing.

quote: THE TWENTIETH REMOVE
text: 3 or 4 miles away from the camp they attacked Sudbury from

quote: We went about three or four miles, and there they built a great wigwam, big enough to hold an hundred Indians, which they did in preparation to a great day of dancing.
Then he overtook her, and began to rant as if he had been mad, and made her go back again in the rain; so that I never saw her till I saw her in Charlestown.
text: Her sister tries to see her, but doesn't.

quote: My daughter was also now about a mile off
text: Her daughter was also near, but she didn't get to see her.

quote: I told them I thought they had killed the Englishman (for they had in the meantime informed me that an Englishman was come). They said, no. They shot over his horse and under and before his horse, and they pushed him this way and that way, at their pleasure, showing what they could do.
text: They terrorize an Englishman that shows up.

quote: Amongst other things which my husband sent me, there came a pound of tobacco, which I sold for nine shillings in money; for many of the Indians for want of tobacco, smoked hemlock
text: Her husband sent her tobacco?

quote: In the morning Mr. Hoar invited the Sagamores to dinner; but when we went to get it ready we found that they had stolen the greatest part of the provision Mr. Hoar had brought, out of his bags, in the night.
text: The Indians stole food and cloth from the Englishman.

quote: He was dressed in his holland shirt, with great laces sewed at the tail of it; he had his silver buttons, his white stockings, his garters were hung round with shillings, and he had girdles of wampum upon his head and shoulders. She had a kersey coat, and covered with girdles of wampum from the loins upward. Her arms from her elbows to her hands were covered with bracelets; there were handfuls of necklaces about her neck, and several sorts of jewels in her ears. She had fine red stockings, and white shoes, her hair powdered and face painted red, that was always before black.
text: Her master and mistress get dressed up to dance.

quote: When we were lain down, my master went out of the wigwam, and by and by sent in an Indian called James the Printer, who told Mr. Hoar, that my master would let me go home tomorrow, if he would let him have one pint of liquors.
text: Her master says he'll give her back for a pint of alcohol.

quote: Then Mr. Hoar called his own Indians, Tom and Peter, and bid them go and see whether he would promise it before them three; and if he would, he should have it; which he did, and he had it.
text: The Englishman gets "his Indians" to find him alcohol.

quote: My master after he had had his drink, quickly came ranting into the wigwam again, and called for Mr. Hoar, drinking to him, and saying, he was a good man, and then again he would say, "hang him rogue."
text: Her master gets drunk off of a pint.

quote: On Tuesday morning they called their general court (as they call it) to consult and determine, whether I should go home or no. And they all as one man did seemingly consent to it, that I should go home; except Philip, who would not come among them.
text: Then the General Court decides she should go home?

quote: Then Philip smelling the business called me to him, and asked me what I would give him, to tell me some good news, and speak a good word for me. I told him I could not tell what to give him. I would [give him] anything I had, and asked him what he would have? He said two coats and twenty shillings in money, and half a bushel of seed corn, and some tobacco. I thanked him for his love; but I knew the good news as well as the crafty fox.
text: Metacomet shows up and makes her give him things in return for good news.

quote: I say, that then our army should want provision, and be forced to leave their pursuit and return homeward; and the very next week the enemy came upon our town, like bears bereft of their whelps, or so many ravenous wolves, rending us and our lambs to death.
text: There had been army men at her town until they left to get more provisions a week before the attack. (Unsurprisingly, the Indians had been starving too.)

quote: Thus did they scoff at us, as if the English would be a quarter of a year getting ready.
text: The Indians were scornful of the English army.

quote: fled before them till they came to Banquang river
text: The Indians had been running from the fresh English army by crossing an impassable river.

quote: I did not see (all the time I was among them) one man, woman, or child, die with hunger.
text: None of the Indians died of hunger, even though the English strategy was starve them out.

quote: They would eat horse's guts, and ears, and all sorts of wild birds which they could catch; also bear, venison, beaver, tortoise, frogs, squirrels, dogs, skunks, rattlesnakes; yea, the very bark of trees;
text: The Indians ate everything.

quote: eleven weeks and five days

one week passed without the fury of the enemy, and some desolation by fire and sword upon one place or other. They mourned (with their black faces) for their own losses, yet triumphed and rejoiced in their inhumane, and many times devilish cruelty to the English.
text: The Indians attacked Englishpeople a lot.

quote: At first they were all against it, except my husband would come for me, but afterwards they assented to it, and seemed much to rejoice in it; some asked me to send them some bread, others some tobacco, others shaking me by the hand, offering me a hood and scarfe to ride in; not one moving hand or tongue against it.
text: They didn't want her to go home until they did. Then they wanted her to send them things.

quote: About the sun going down, Mr. Hoar, and myself, and the two Indians came to Lancaster, and a solemn sight it was to me.
text: She finally returns to Lancaster.

quote: now not one Christian to be seen, nor one house left standing
text: Lancaster was destroyed.

quote: we came to Concord
text: Concord

quote: where
text: Meets her brother and brother-in-law.

quote: She being shot down by the house was partly burnt, so that those who were at Boston at the desolation of the town, and came back afterward, and buried the dead, did not know her
text: Her brother-in-law had buried his own wife without recognizing her (burnt).

quote: Being recruited with food and raiment we went to Boston that day, where I met with my dear husband, but the thoughts of our dear children, one being dead, and the other we could not tell where, abated our comfort each to other
text: She goes to Boston and meets her husband.

quote: The twenty pounds, the price of my redemption, was raised by some Boston gentlemen, and Mrs. Usher, whose bounty and religious charity, I would not forget to make mention of
text: Her ransom was raised by charity.

quote: they brought in my sister, and goodwife Kettle.
text: Her sister and a woman she knew were also ransomed/returned.

quote: And as we were riding along (God is the wise disposer of all things) between Ipswich and Rowley we met with Mr. William Hubbard, who told us that our son Joseph was come in to Major Waldron's, and another with him, which was my sister's son.
text: She gets news of her son and nephew (who are at Major Waldron's). Between Ipswich and Rowley.

quote: Newbury
text: Newbury

quote: Salisbury
text: Salisbury

quote: his daughter was come in at Providence
text: They hear her daughters is at Providence.

quote: Our son being nearest, we went to him first, to Portsmouth, where we met with him, and with the Major also,
text: They retrieve their son from Portsmouth for 7 pounds.

quote: Charlestown
text: Charlestown

quote: Rehoboth than Rhode Island
text: Rehoboth and Rhode Island

quote: But the carts which carried provision to the English army, being guarded, brought her with them to Dorchester, where we received her safe.
text: They retrieved her daughter at Dorchester.

quote: Thus she traveled three days together, not knowing whither she was going
text: She traveled 3 days with an Indian woman to come to Providence

quote: the South Church in Boston hired an house for us. Then we removed from Mr. Shepard's, those cordial friends, and went to Boston, where we continued about three-quarters of a year
text: The family moves to Boston

quote: the Indians laid hold of us, pulling me one way, and the children another, and said, "Come go along with us"; I told them they would kill me: they answered, if I were willing to go along with them, they would not hurt me.
text: Indians separate her from her children.

quote: And as miserable was the waste that was there made of horses, cattle, sheep, swine, calves, lambs, roasting pigs, and fowl (which they had plundered in the town), some roasting, some lying and burning, and some boiling to feed our merciless enemies; who were joyful enough, though we were disconsolate.
text: They also took livestock from the town?

quote: All was gone, my husband gone (at least separated from me, he being in the Bay; and to add to my grief, the Indians told me they would kill him as he came homeward), my children gone, my relations and friends gone, our house and home and all our comforts—within door and without—all was gone (except my life), and I knew not but the next moment that might go too.
text: What happened to her kids? Confused. And her husband's away at sea.

quote: A very wearisome and tedious day I had of it; what with my own wound, and my child's being so exceeding sick, and in a lamentable condition with her wound.
text: It's her daughter.

quote: This day there came to me one Robert Pepper (a man belonging to Roxbury) who was taken in Captain Beers's fight, and had been now a considerable time with the Indians;
text: What do the Indians want with English captives for so long?

quote: gathered a great company together about her and stripped her naked, and set her in the midst of them, and when they had sung and danced about her (in their hellish manner) as long as they pleased they knocked her on head, and the child in her arms with her.
text: Pregnant woman wants to go home; Indians strip her, beat her and her child, and dance around her.

quote: For they went as if they had gone for their lives, for some considerable way, and then they made a stop, and chose some of their stoutest men, and sent them back to hold the English army in play whilst the rest escaped
text: Indians are running from the English.

quote: I carried the knife in, and my master asked me to give it him, and I was not a little glad that I had anything that they would accept of, and be pleased with.
text: She gives her master a knife and is glad that she's made him happy.

quote: He showed me the way to my son
text: But her master shows her the way.

quote: He told me also, that awhile before, his master (together with other Indians) were going to the French for powder; but by the way the Mohawks met with them, and killed four of their company, which made the rest turn back again, for it might have been worse with him, had he been sold to the French, than it proved to be in his remaining with the Indians.
text: Her son's Indians attempt to trade with the French, but the Mohawks prevent them from doing so.

quote: They told me I lied, and taking up a hatchet, they came to me, and said they would knock me down if I stirred out again, and so confined me to the wigwam.
text: She's no longer allowed out of the wigwam.

quote: Then I went home to my mistress's wigwam; and they told me I disgraced my master with begging, and if I did so any more, they would knock me in the head. I told them, they had as good knock me in head as starve me to death.
text: Her mistress tells her to stop begging for food. She tells them they can beat her or kill her by starvation.

quote: Hearing that my son was come to this place, I went to see him, and found him lying flat upon the ground.
text: She visits her son.

quote: she had been gone three weeks into the Narragansett country to fetch corn
text: They have corn stores in Narragansett country.

quote: We were at this place and time about two miles from [the] Connecticut river.
text: 2 miles from the Connecticut river.

quote: Here I parted from my daughter Mary
text: last time she sees Mary

quote: I offered the money to my master, but he bade me keep it
text: Indian master lets her keep the English money?

quote: Here lived a sorry Indian
text: Stopped at place of an Indian (many indians?)

quote: I went to the same squaw, who had a kettle of ground nuts boiling. I asked her to let me boil my piece of bear in her kettle, which she did, and gave me some ground nuts to eat with it: and I cannot but think how pleasant it was to me.
text: This woman is very nice to her.

quote: he would not, but said he would go on, and come to us again in three days
text: Master continues onwards.

quote: our course toward the Baytowns;
text: headed towards Baytowns

quote: I must go to Wachusett to my master
text: She's Wachusett-bound, where her master is.

quote: Then I took it of the child, and eat it myself, and savory it was to my taste.
text: She stole food from a child?

quote: One of my elder sisters' children, named William, had then his leg broken, which the Indians perceiving, they knocked him on [his] head.
text: Nephew beaten. (dead or unconscious? unclear)

quote: last an old Indian bade me to come to him, and his squaw gave me some ground nuts; she gave me also something to lay under my head, and a good fire we had;
text: An old Indian couple took her in for the night.

quote: Of thirty-seven persons who were in this one house, none escaped either present death, or a bitter captivity, save only one, who might say as he, "And I only am escaped alone to tell the News" (Job 1.15). There were twelve killed, some shot, some stabbed with their spears, some knocked down with their hatchets.
text: 12 out of 37 people killed. 1 escapes to tell the news. (Big house!)

quote: we must go five miles up the river, and then go over it.
text: Recrossing the river?

quote: yet not one of them offered the least imaginable miscarriage to me.
text: None of the Indians she passed were at all bad to her.

quote: When I was there, there came an Indian to look after me, who when he had found me, kicked me all along.
text: But another Indian makes her go back to her master's camp.

quote: when we came to lie down they bade me to go out, and lie somewhere else,
text: She wasn't allowed to sleep in the wigwam that night.

quote: I confess I could not much condole with them
text: She didn't feel bad for her mistress losing a child. There's a surprise.

quote: We came to Banquang river again that day, near which we abode a few days.
text: Banquaug river again

quote: I was so weak and feeble, that I reeled as I went along, and thought there I must end my days at last, after my bearing and getting through so many difficulties
text: She has a lot of problems crossing the river.

quote: first sight of them, for they were dressed in English apparel, with hats, white neckcloths, and sashes about their waists; and ribbons upon their shoulders;
text: Indians in English clothing.

quote: Englishman stripped naked, and lying dead upon the ground, but knew not who it was.
text: dead naked Englishman

quote: In this town there were four English children, captives; and one of them my own sister's.
text: She comes across one of her nieces.

quote: One of the Indians that came from Medfield fight, had brought some plunder, came to me, and asked me, if I would have a Bible, he had got one in his basket.
text: An Indian brings her a Bible from Medfield.

quote: On that very day came the English army after them to this river, and saw the smoke of their wigwams, and yet this river put a stop to them. God did not give them courage or activity to go over after us.
text: English army gives up the chase at the river.

quote: Yet it pleased them to go but one mile that night, and there we stayed two days.
text: Only moved one mile, and stayed there two days.

quote: we traveled about half a day or little more, and came to a desolate place in the wilderness, where there were no wigwams or inhabitants before; we came about the middle of the afternoon to this place,
text: half day's travel. stop in the middle of nowhere

quote: being hungry, I went again back to the place we were before at, to get something to eat
text: She walks back to ninth remove to get food.

quote: My mistress's papoose was sick, and it died that night, and there was one benefit in it—that there was more room.
text: Her mistress's baby dies, and she gets put out of the wigwam again.

quote: split open his bowels
text: Graphic detail, carnage

quote: heathen
text: "pagan". Descriptions of Indians have a religious backdrop.

quote: blood running down to our heels
text: explicit reference to blood. Third or so mention in this passage

quote: I must turn my back upon the town
text: note how removes/chapters begin in the present tense, and position the reader in the middle of the scene. Verb tense occasionally changes in the middle of a passage

quote: knock your child in the head
text: repeated mention of "knocking in the head". Why?

quote: and that Scripture came to my hand
text: opens the Bible at random

quote: there was one benefit in it—that there was more room
text: oddly matter-of-factly. The narrator has grown numb to death

quote: papoose
text: A young North American Indian child

quote: sannup
text: A married male Native American

quote: I told them the skin was off my back, but I had no other comforting answer from them than this: that it would be no matter if my head were off too.
text: they want her alive?

quote: I told her I would not. Then my mistress bade me give it, but still I said no. The maid told me if I would not give her a piece, she would tear a piece off it. I told her I would tear her coat then. With that my mistress rises up, and take up a stick big enough to have killed me, and struck at me with it.
text: conflict. example of Mary Rowlandson retaliating against her captors.

quote: When I lived in prosperity, having the comforts of the world about me, my relations by me, my heart cheerful, and taking little care for anything, and yet seeing many, whom I preferred before myself, under many trials and afflictions, in sickness, weakness, poverty, losses, crosses, and cares of the world, I should be sometimes jealous least I should have my portion in this life, and that Scripture would come to my mind
text: she wished for affliction when she recognized that she was living in great prosperity

quote: But to return: the Indians laid hold of us, pulling me one way, and the children another, and said, "Come go along with us"; I told them they would kill me: they answered, if I were willing to go along with them, they would not hurt me.
text: she would not be killed, she would be held captive

quote: About this time I began to think that all my hopes of restoration would come to nothing. I thought of the English army, and hoped for their coming, and being taken by them, but that failed. I hoped to be carried to Albany, as the Indians had discoursed before, but that failed also.
text: feelings of hopelessness and desperation

quote: I had often before this said that if the Indians should come, I should choose rather to be killed by them than taken alive, but when it came to the trial my mind changed
text: change of perspective. she had thought about being captured by Native Americans before?

quote: It is not my tongue, or pen, can express the sorrows of my heart, and bitterness of my spirit that I had at this departure
text: describing how she can't explain it

quote: that there was no mercy for me, that the blessings were gone, and the curses come in their room, and that I had lost my opportunity
text: describes her negative feelings turning positive after reading the Bible

quote: so it must be, that I must sit all this cold winter night upon the cold snowy ground, with my sick child in my arms, looking that every hour would be the last of its life; and having no Christian friend near me, either to comfort or help me
text: she thinks that this suffering is designed for her and her alone, she appreciates the solitude and sees it as a chance to become closer to her religion since it is a significant affliction

quote: your master will knock your child in the head," and then a second, and then a third, "your master will quickly knock your child in the head.
text: is there any comfort gained from having her child "quickly" knocked in the head? Is this their attempts to make things a little (very little) easier/

quote: I have thought since of the wonderful goodness of God to me in preserving me in the use of my reason and senses in that distressed time, that I did not use wicked and violent means to end my own miserable life
text: thanking God for the strength not to commit suicide; it's interesting that she refers to her emotions as opposed to actually expressing them
